cab.content: (THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HER BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT)"- -- -----secret.(54) 270 COPY NO.17th August, 1954CABINETABOLITION OF VISAS FOR GERMANS AND AUSTRIANSMemorandum by the Secretary of State for the Home department and Minister for Welsh AffairsFollowing their discussion on 29th July of the for*eign Secretary'proposal that visas should no longer be required for German and Austrianvisitors to this country, my colleagues invited me to circulate a statementindicating the number of Germans and Austrians who had come to the UnitedKingdom in recent years for visits of less than three months (C. C. (54) 56thConclusions, Minute 6).2. Separate figures for foreign visitors coming to the United kingdom for less than three months are not kept, but the figures given below show thenumber of Germans and Austrians who came to the United Kingdom in eachof the years 1951, 1952 and 1953 for visits not exceeding six months. Thegreat majority of these visitors were allowed to land for three months orless. I am also circulating, for comparison, similar figures showing thenumber of French, Italian, Belgian, Dutch and United States visitorsin these years.3. The figures are:- 1951 1952 1953Germans 40,174 49,577 63,363Austrians 6,648 5,724 7,061French 102,715 99,612 111,979Italians 19,173 19,598 22,482Belgians 45,970 41,001 41,379Dutch 59,689 52,337 56,810United States citizens 120,876 156,658 177,7214. The Cabinet agreed that, subject to any points Ministers might wishto raise in the light of these figures, German and Austrian nationals visitingthe United Kingdom for less than three months should no longer be requiredto obtain a British visa. Although an agreement cannot be reached this year in time to affect holiday traffic, the Foreign Office is anxious to make astatement as soon as possible, and I should be grateful if my colleaguescould let me have, not later than 23rd August, any further points whichthey wish to raise.D.M.F.Home Office, S.W.1.16th August, 1954.
